reviewText: I believe this to be the best Ed Sullivan show of all time.I also enjoy the tv commericals.This was a time when familes would spend time together.This was and will always be a one time event in television history, it will never come again.The Beatles and Ed Sullivan go together like peanut butter and jelly.A great combination.

reviewText: I got this as a gift for my younger sister.  She was a Beatles fan before I even heard of them.  We watched it at her house with her grand kids and loved every minute as the memories of our youth came rushing back.  I cannot hear "I Wanna Hold Your Hand" or "Please, Please Me" without flashing back to the late 60's and early 70's.  As Yogi said, "It was deja vu all over again."  It was one of the best gifts ever.  Oh, and the packaging was fine also.

reviewText: I got this for 13.99 at Target. It's a good DVD. The audio is pretty good on stereo, but is pretty lifeless in the 5.1 remix. I have a good 5.1 system, with proper 5.1 hook ups, and the surround mix is more mono than the mono is! Regardless, it's cool to see this historic event on DVD at all. The video looks decent enoujgh fort the age, it's soft but there's not any specks and stuff really. It's pretty enjoyable and if you are a beatle fan you should get it!

reviewText: I especially like the show they did from Miami, but all of the appearances on the Ed Sullivan Show are contained in this collection. Among other things, the DVDs provide great examples of the old-time variety show genre that used to rule prime time, including commercials. You can, if you wish, avoid the other segments of the shows and just focus on the Beatles, in case you're not into magicians, jugulars, and acrobats. The segments featuring the Beatles stand out as little gems in the flow of less memorable content. The guys look good and sound great, although Ed's patronizing use of the word "youngsters" is a bit off-putting.
summary: A must-have for fans of the mop-tops

To have The Beatles' entire Ed Sullivan Shows on DVD is like finding gold bars in the back yard. 1964...The fab four....and everything changed. Beatlemania! The best!

reviewText: The 4 Complete Ed Sullivan Shows Starring The Beatles:  The Beatles have no less than 20 segments on this DVD which makes it an indispensible item for the fan.  Since these are the complete shows, we get many other acts, some of which are fantastic and others that leave you scratching your puzzled head.  Of course, some acts were fine at the time but are now hopelessly outdated.  There are however a few nice surprises along the way.  It is great to have these shows in their entirety but you will make good use of your `skip' button.
summary: For Beatles, history and nostalgia (with a touch of nausea)
Title: N/A

reviewText: Since this DVD set isn't out yet - and I can't possibly have seen it - this "review" is based on things I have heard from some reliable Beatles sources.This release will be pretty similar to the SOFA Home Entertainment release from 2003, with the addition of some 13 additional minutes of footage. This additional content will consist of a brief London interview with The Beatles by Sullivan which apparently has not been seen since the day it aired (May 24, 1964); a 1966 b&w; commercial for Beatles dolls introduced by Sullivan in color; and the host reading a 1967 telegram from The Beatles congratulating him on the renaming of the studio to "The Ed Sullivan Theater."Also, the Miami, FL show is being refurbished as the original taping (which was done in a hotel and not in a TV studio) was pretty weak.It's up to you to decide if this is worth it or not (if you already have the previous SOFA release). I probably will not bother.
summary: Not too different from the 2003 release
Title: N/A

reviewText: I never purchased earlier versions of this so I cannot comment on the quality of this vis-a-vis them.  I do know there are technical limitations to what can be done with kinescopes and aged tape. Those who think or want these things to look current may be missing the point. There are many, many of us who believe the world turned around on February 9, 1964 with this first opportunity for the masses to see The Beatles in action. (OK, they were on Paar and some other shows but rememeber, Sullivan's show was the cynosure,,,it was legitimcay; that's why - at least in this case - Epstein was brilliant)Moreso, look at what else was on these shows. How much would you pay for a DVD of Frank Gorshin or Two Ton Tessie O'Shea...or even Georgia Brown???? Sullivan brought vaudeville to TV and The Beatles changed that. From here on, Rock 'n' Roll became normal for family vieiwng. How many groups did we get to see after these performances. This was a tipping point.But besides that. Watch these four sets of performances - you can set the DVD to just show The Beatles. Watch the maturing in their performances across the three February shows and then see the quantum leap in how they are at that 1965 show. They had played Shea the month before; probably the first stadium concert ever. Notice also how much better the Sullivan showm techies handle the staging itself.This is historic stuff!
Title: N/A

reviewerName: John D. Muir "oldies and pies lover"
reviewText: Since I was in England when these shows were recorded, it was interesting to me to see what the full shows looked like. I'd seen the performances of The Beatles many times, but not the context in which they were set. There were several things that were surprising to me.First, I hadn't realised how minimal the staging was. Not only were there no fancy sets, there were hardly any sets at all. Most of the acts just came out and performed in front of curtains. Coupled with that was the low-key nature of the presentation, exemplified by the style of Mr. Sullivan himself. These days it seems that presenters don't feel that they've done their job unless they scream their introductions. Ed Sullivan simply said a few words and then allowed the acts to speak for themselves.Second, an area which has improved considerably is the lighting of the stage. Evidently at that time lights were very bright and very hot, with the result that the performers were visibly drenched in sweat after the first couple of minutes. Paul was glistening like a marathon runner and poor Mitzi Gaynor was actually dripping. I found it quite distracting, as obviously did Ms. Gaynor.Third, if indeed these are the full shows, I was surprised by how limited the commercial interruptions were. There was generally only one or at the most two advertisements between each act and The Beatles and Mitzi Gaynor, as the biggest stars on view, were able to perform several numbers without commercial interruptions. The commercials themselves were rather endearing in their earnestness, striving to show what good quality the products were. Only cosmetics and medical products appear to have that as their primary objective now, most of the others being either humorous or appealing to the desire for status.I'm not a believer that everything was better in the good old days, and a program like this would have to be considerably reworked to get any kind of an audience now. However, it is commendable that these shows are still available to allow people like myself to see what America was watching in 1964. The British TV companies, alas, didn't do nearly as good a job at retaining archival material and much of what was broadcast in Britain at that time has been lost forever.Well worth purchasing for fans of The Beatles, Ed Sullivan and the early 1960s period.

Title: N/A

reviewText: Although these shows are of high historical value, I found the picture and sound on this particular release to be not much better than the original SOFA DVD issued a few years ago. There is a little more bass and less overall compression in the sound but the audience noise (screaming) is still painful. The picture displays more contrast at the expense of gray-area detail and less overall brightness.If you already have these shows on DVD, there's not enough improvement here to justify buying them again.
summary: Not enough improvement to justify a re-purchase.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Every Sunday night it was Ed Sullivan & the Cartwright family. I watched in both amazement & dismay. Beatles were of course amazing but I don't think I ever saw my step father more outraged. I was afraid he would turn it off but much to my relief he settled down & rode it out. It is important that these shows continue to be available but if you already bought the version a few years back you probably don't need to buy it again unless like me your copy was lost or damaged. The only thing I would have liked would be to have the Beatles performances alone as well as the complete shows for the times you just can't stomach the entire show & want to just kick back & let it roll. Still anybody that loves the Beatles owes it to themself to ad this to their collection
Title: N/A

reviewText: Having lived through those moments in the early 60's when the Beatles and Rolling Stones came to America, I thought it would be great to see their original performances.  I am very happy with the video, but find the original performances kind of humerous because of some of the stage gaffs like microphones not being at the correct height, and the sound not being fed into the mixer properly.  I had forgotten that Ed Sullivan devoted a large part of three shows in a row just to the Beatles.  Ed really knew how to find talented people for his shows.  I also chuckled about all the times he told the Beatles they were nice and well behaved boys that would make England proud.  Definitely worth watching and adding to your Beatles film collection!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Bought this for my father who was 32 years old when it aired. He always remembered this particular show because, being a man who grew up in Puerto Rico, he couldn't understand what was wrong with the American girls who were going crazy for these guys. He would learn later on of course. But at 81 it was something that he mentioned to me of his memories and I looked for it, found it and got it for him. Hes is very happy with it.

reviewText: Ladies and Gentlemen, THE BEATLES!!!!! (incessant Screaming ensues....)It must be curious if you were not there, but crowds reacted similarly to Bing Crosby, Frank Sinatra, Elvis and others before and since. It was virtually impossible to actually hear the performances over the screaming fans, but Ed Sullivan kept them at bay better than Roger Waters at a Pink Floyd concert. I don't know how to relate the excitement of these shows, but as an historical time capsule, complete with commercials and the other acts which preceded them and had to follow them, this so much beats the heck out of snippets and excerpts.Imagine yourself sitting down in front of the television with the family and watching Sullivan's Variety show each week. It's an interesting experience to say the least.
summary: Ladies and Gentlemen, THE BEATLES!!!!! (incessant Screaming ensues....)

reviewText: During the first two shows, it seems Ringo is not feeling well but that could just be Ringo.  I remember watching the first night with my grandmother and enjoyed the reaction to the girls in the audience as much as the Beatles themselves.  This was Rock history without any doubt and if some think the video and audio were not first rate, remember these TV shows were not equipped with DOLBY and any advanced systems studios today have.  This double set is truly historical and it is a gas watching the Beatles enjoy themselves doing their first live US perormances on television.  Great discs, great entertainment.
